Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Ecosystem Indicators of Productivity of Lithic-Mulched Fields

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates Pre-Columbian agricultural fields which relied on runoff irrigation technologies unique to the ancient southwestern United States. Understanding how runoff irrigation and water management influenced vegetative productivity is critical to understanding the widespread occurrence of this technology in certain parts of the region and has implications for understanding how humans have shaped contemporary ecosystems. In addition to contributing to a scientific understanding of the function and persistence of runoff irrigation technology, this research addresses questions about the benefits for the application of traditional farming practices in the modern day. Because these features developed in a water limited environments, and are known only through archaeological research, facts regarding their character and function contribute information important to agriculture in present day drylands and have implications for water diversion and conservation. Finally, the project will contribute to undergraduate student training in field and laboratory techniques in he fields of archaeology and environmental science.

The relative productivity of ancient runoff irrigated fields will be measured at scales ranging from centuries to single years in northern New Mexico. Particular focus will be given to fields that were mulched with pebbles and cobbles. Fields of this type are particularly abundant, and the technology was apparently well developed in this area. Soil and vegetation characteristics have been documented for other dryland field types in the Southwest, but few comparable studies have been conducted on rock-mulched fields. The study will rectify this knowledge gap and generate data that will allow comparison across the Southwest. Year-to-year changes in the width of growth rings for trees established on fields will be measured to determine how water conserving features may buffer trees from periodic droughts. Relative levels of organic material in soils, which are derived from plant matter, track how water conserving features alter plant productivity over the last few centuries. Together, soil chemistry and tree-rings will help answer questions about how ancient agricultural investments continue to effect contemporary ecosystem productivity, and the role this infrastructure played in supporting the large communities of northern New Mexico from 1300 A.D. until Spanish contact in the 1600s.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary over-arching goal of the project was to examine lithic mulched fields in northern New Mexico and examine ways in which they did, or did not, facilitate late prehistoric population expansion and agricultural intensification into a marginal area.

To address the objectives of the study, the following data were collected from agricultural field complexes around Poshu?Owingeh,  a large prehistoric pueblo in northern New Mexico: (1) soil characteristics indicative of water balance, (2) pollen concentrations indicative of field use, (3) properties of soil quality to determine legacy impacts of prehistoric agriculture, and (4) tree-growth rates and below ground carbon stocks to determine if fields maintained legacy impacts into the modern period.. Specific activities included pedestrian survey and digital mapping; hand excavation, description, and sampling of soil profiles; and collection of pollen samples and tree-ring cross-sections and cores from living trees established on and off former agricultural fields.

 One of the most significant findings is that the field areas near Poshu?Owingeh contain the highest concentrations of cotton pollen ever observed in relict Northern Rio Grande agroecosystems. The significance for specialization in non-food crops like cotton, indicates more complex intra-and inter-regional exchange than previously believed. Our current hypothesis is that cotton may have been used to make ceremonial garb and traded via religious organizations throughout the Tewa world.

Field observations and select soil characteristics associated with water balance support the hypothesis that lithic mulch is a run-off irrigation technology. Based on the depth of reconstructed water penetration, gravel mulch must have functioned in concert with runoff from summer storms. The timing of the North American Monsoon and the reconstructed function of gravel mulch suggest that it specifically benefited cotton by supplying water in excess of precipitation during a crucial developmental stage. This study found no evidence for soil degradation nor a significant increase in tree productivity (calculated as average biomass yield over tree lifetime). This study returned evidence that lithic mulch may reduce tree mortality, perhaps by buffering soil moisture deficits.

 

The project comprises the dissertation portion of Mr. Kessler's PhD studies.  He  organized and conducted all phases of the research, including developing the research questions, gathering field data, analyzing (or contracting analyses) and interpreting the data, and synthesizing the results. He successfully defended his PhD dissertation in December 2019.
